Ottawa, September 10, 1926.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan has nominated Miss Florence Scholefield for the position as assistant teacher and matron at the Little Pines Indian Day School. The Department is approving of her appointment, with salary at the rate of $45 per teaching month. Her appointment dates from August 17th, last.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

S. L. Macdonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Ont.
### DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

#### TEACHERS' SALARIES

**For Quarter Ended September 30th 1926**

| Name of Teacher | Name of School | Annual Grant or Salary | Amount Due | Address to Which Cheque is to be Sent |
|-----------------|---------------|------------------------|------------|--------------------------------------|
| Annie L. Cunningham | Little Pines | $900.00                | $157.50 (Paid for 1½ mos.) |                                      |
| Florence Scholefield | do          | $450.00                | $67.50 (Paid for 1½ mos.) |                                      |

**Remarks:**

Miss Cunningham reopened school at beginning of second week of August and is being paid for 1½ months.

Miss Cruikshank resigned and has been succeeded by Miss Scholefield at $45 a teaching month. The latter began duties on August 17th, 1926, and is paid for 1½ months.

Ottawa, January 15, 1927.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that the Church of England authorities of the Diocese of Saskatchewan have informed the Department of the resignation of Miss Florence Scholefield as assistant teacher and matron of the Little Pines Indian Day School, and have nominated the services of Miss T. M. Faithfull to succeed her. Miss Faithfull holds a second class Alberta certificate and has had several years' experience. The Department is approving of her appointment, with salary at the rate of $45 per teaching month.

I shall be pleased if you will give Miss Faithfull every assistance you can in her work at this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

S. L. Macdonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Battleford,
Sask.
Dear Sir,

Will you kindly pay to Rev. E. Ahnatau all the money coming to me from the Indian Department for duties performed at Little Pines School during the December quarter. This is in payment of money he advanced me today.

I am returning to England as my father is dangerously ill.

Yours respectfully,
F. Schofield

S. L. Macdonald Esq.
Indian Agent,
Butteford
Sask.

NOTE: This order for payment of salary was forwarded by Capt. Macdonald under cover of his letter of January 11/27. See file 105-2-1.

Peeq. No. 4793, drawn in favor of Miss Schofield and sent on 13/27.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6287, file 612-3, part 1)
Ottawa, January 18, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, informing the Department of the resignation of Miss Scholefield, assistant teacher of the Little Pines Indian Day School. In this connection I would refer you to official letter of the 15th instant approving of the appointment of Miss I. M. Faithfull to succeed Miss Scholefield.

The order which you forwarded from Miss Scholefield for the payment of her December quarter salary to Rev. E. Ahenakew was also received. The salary due Miss Scholefield for that quarter, to the amount of $125.00, was sent by cheque No. 4793, drawn in her favour, in your care on the 13th instant. If Mr. Ahenakew cannot arrange to cash this cheque, it should be returned to the Department, when a cheque in his favour will be issued. It is noted that Miss Scholefield's resignation took effect on the 7th instant. If there is any balance of salary due her for the few days she taught during the present month, I have to request that you will state the exact number of days taught, and if any amount is due therefor, a cheque will be sent in favour of Mr. Ahenakew.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

S. L. Macdonald Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.

CANADA
Ottawa, April 23, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, regarding the services being performed by Miss Cunningham as teacher and Miss Faithfull as assistant teacher and matron at the Little Pine Indian Day School. In reply I have to say it is noted that both these ladies are performing satisfactory service.

Regarding your request that they be granted an increase in salary, I have to say that, as our funds this year are extremely limited, the Department will, in view of the salary at present allowed Miss Faithfull, grant her an increase from the 1st instant at the rate of $15 per teaching month. This will make the total salary allowed her from that date at the rate of $60 per teaching month, and she will be rated as assistant teacher from the date mentioned. Please inform Miss Faithfull of the increase allowed her.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

S. L. Macdonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.

For Amateur Painters

Paint, applied to any surface actually covers that surface with a coat of mail, metallic effect in technical parlance. This plating, or armor, protects the surface from the destructive action of corrosion or "oxidation"—of the air's oxygen, and from the mechanical action (in the case of paint surface exposed to the weather) of the elements—rain, snow, chemical action, the attrition of dust, etc.

Every layer of this plating that is put on any surface—every "coat of paint," that is,—of course increases the thickness of that armor.

This is the reason why a priming coat and even two thin coats of paint will always yield at least two thick coats without any priming beneath,—something it is usually hard to make the amateur painter understand. The oil in the priming fills the pores of the surface covered, and therefore economizes the oil in the after coats, and it leaves the thin films of metallic oxides on the surface which provides a good foundation for the thicker films that are on top of it.

Now, the amount of resistance paint can offer to the destructive forces named depends upon what that paint is made of, how it is made, and how it is applied. This is the question to ask for the two factors, the user for the other one. If you do your own painting, you can safely answer for it if you follow the Hints About Painting printed in another part of this leaflet—and do not endeavor to improve them.

Choose M. L. Paint not because it looks alright. Any paint looks alright.

Choose M. L. Paint not because its price compares with other brands. Any half-way decent paint costs about the same as M. L. Brand.

Choose M. L. Paint not because of its covering power of 400 square feet, two coats, to the gallon. Some paints claim to cover more surface,—but how long will the covering last?

Choose M. L. Paint because it will do all any other paint does in beautifying; and fully a third more in protecting.

HOW MUCH PAINT WILL IT TAKE?

For outside house-painting, to find the quantity of M. L. Paint needed for two coats over a priming coat—Multiply the average height of the outer walls, from ground to cornice, in feet, by the distance around the building in feet. Divide the total by 400. The answer will show the number of gallons required to cover two coats.

For inside work—One quart of M. L. Paint will finish, with two coats, both sides of any ordinary door, the frames of two windows, and all the rest of the woodwork of a room.

For floors—One quart of M. L. Special Floor Paint will put two coats on a floor 12x16 ft., or about 200 square ft. of area.

Floglaze, the ideal floor finish, will surface 500 square feet to the gallon with a brilliant, washable and wear-proof surface.

Colors marked thus (*) are Higher in Price.
WHY?

Can you answer this question—"Why did you buy M. L. Paint rather than Somebody else?"

Our answer is simply this:

M. L. Paint covers more surface to the gallon, costs less money per square foot of surface covered, lasts longer and looks better than any other paint there.

That is true of M. L. Paint because we not only use the best materials the markets of the paint-world sell—the purest quality of White Lead; the best quality of Oxide of Zinc; the best quality of coloring pigments made by the best known paint raw materialists, and so made RIGHT; the best Pure Raw Linseed Oil—but we put these together by processes improved beyond the knowledge of most paint makers, and with machinery not excelled anywhere.

And to these ingredients, selected with the greatest care for quality, we add—in the case of all our indoor and outdoor paints—special ingredient peculiar to the M. L. Brand.

This ingredient is the outcome of years of ceaseless study and experiment, expended freely with the purpose of improving M. L. Paints to the last degree of excellence. That study and experiment has been at our own expense, not at the consumer's; and it has paid off in at least uniform and unwavering quality in M. L. Paints which insure the buyer off the premises against the many paint-troubles he must suffer with other kinds.

With the addition of this ingredient, thoroughly incorporated with the other M. L. materials by special methods, every square inch of surface covered with our indoor and outdoor paints will resist the elements longer and preserve its fresh, new appearance better, than is otherwise possible.

Durability is the big thing to consider in buying paints,—for the real measure of paint value depends upon the length of time that paint will endure. As the chief consideration is the life of the paint, and not the price of the paint itself, it must be clear that any paint which—like the M. L. Brand—will last three years to another brand's two, is at least one-third cheaper in the long run.

Hints About Painting

If you use M. L. Paints and obey the directions here given, you cannot fail to get a painting job that will be thoroughly and lastingly satisfactory to you. And, moreover, you will get full value for what you spend in money or in labor, or both.

Preferably, employ a practical painter to do any considerable painting. He knows how, far better than you could learn unless you spend much time learning as he does. His charges will be reasonable enough; and the job will be far better done than you could do it, at best. But, if for any reason you cannot hire a painter, these hints will help:

Stir the contents of M. L. cans thoroughly, and from the bottom. Stir a good deal longer and harder than you think is necessary. Then pour the paint, after stirring, from one can to another at least eight times. Twice times is better.

Before applying the heavy paint, use a good priming paint. You can't find a better kind than M. L. Primers. Never use an Ochre Primer. If you do, the after coats will crack, flake or blister,—bound to do so.

Never spread paint on a damp surface, nor on a frost-coated surface.

Never spread paint on a greasy, sooty or smoked surface.

Don't try to paint green lumber, nor lumber full of pitch.

Never put a coat of paint on top of another coat which is not dry.

Always put the paint on thick and spread it out thin, stirring it in thoroughly,—brush it in and brush it in again. This is the "knack" of the practical painter; and it is a knack well worth what he charges to use it.

Don't thin M. L. Paint with anything but raw linseed oil—and be sure it is pure, high grade oil, like the oil that is in M. L. Paint when you get it.

Use—on all new work, at least—a priming coat and two coats of paint. It pays far better in the long run than the two coats alone.

Tenders for Little Pine School-House and Teacher's residence, Saskatchewan.

In January last tenders were called for, for the erection of a school-house and teacher's residence on the Red Pheasant's reserve and also for a school-house and teacher's residence on the Little Pine Reserve, both of which reserves are in the Battleford Agency. Four tenders were received, but only one, that of J.M. Storer, for $6,615.00, which was for the Red Pheasant's buildings and which was accepted by Order in Council of the 21st March, complied with the conditions of the Department's advertisement.

Now tenders were therefore invited for the Little Pine buildings and the tenders mentioned in the report to Council herewith have been received. Of these tenders, which are all regular, that of Theodore Boudreau, in the lowest, and as the Architect of the Department states that it is a reasonable one, it is proposed that it be accepted.

Sub-section 2 of section 36 of the Public Works Act requires that tenders for works to be done by a Department of the Government shall be awarded under the direction of the Governor in Council.

These buildings are required in accordance with an arrangement with the Church Authorities under which the Battleford Industrial School (for which
it has been very difficult to obtain recruits) has to be closed and the Little Pine, Red Pheasant and Le Pas day schools are to be enlarged.

The Battleford Industrial School has been largely recruited through the localities in which the three latter mentioned day schools are situated. The vote for Indian Education (No. 302, Appropriation Act, 1912-13) contains provision for this work.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that your tender for the erection of a teacher's residence and school house on the Little Pine Indian Reserve for the sum of $5965.00, has been accepted. I am enclosing herewith a contract in duplicate which you will be good enough to sign in the presence of a subscribing witness and return both copies to the Department for execution by the Deputy Superintendent General.

I am sending you also under separate cover a copy of the plans and specifications each of which you will be good enough to sign. I am sending also a second copy of the plans and specifications for your own use.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant in reference to the furnishing of the combined day school for the Red Pheasants and Stony Reserves.

In reply I beg to say that the Department considers that it would be advisable to put in double desks of the kind known as double separate, that is with individual seats, as the number of single desks that would be accommodated might not be sufficient for the children that will attend. You may, therefore, purchase desks of this kind and also a teacher's desk and chair. It is not considered necessary to expend the amount mentioned by you in the purchase of a teacher's chair, as an ordinary arm chair will be sufficient. You may also purchase window shades for the school-room.

With regard to the ranges I beg to say that the Department will supply these, as they will be used in the preparation of the mid-day meal for the pupils. Be good enough to consult those interested and ascertain what kind of a range would be suitable and submit an estimate of the cost.

The Department will also supply window shades for the residences on the Red Pheasants and Little Pines Reserves.

Your obedient servant,

J. A. Rowland, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

Re Little Pines Reserve Farm Buildings.

During my inspection on above buildings last week, I found that work had been started on excavation for School-House, so it is evident that Mr Boudreau has received the Plans and Specifications.

Mr Boudreau was not there, but a gang of men were busy digging, and the carpenters cutting material for the cribbing for cement work.

This week I found that the foundation for School-House completed, and about twelve thousand feet of lumber on the ground, some of which I condemned and ordered removed.

Mr Boudreau was not there himself, and there did not appear to be anyone in charge of the work.

Mr Boudreau intends I believe, to take in a partner on this contract, and I would like to know whether the consent of the Dept has been given him, so to do.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Re Little Pines School Buildings.

Mr Boudreau the contractor on above, is making great progress with the construction of these buildings, and I believe that with a little favourable weather will complete his work before the end of November.

Knowing the Dept's immediate need of these buildings, I told Mr Boudreau that the plastering must be completed and dry before the frosty weather came or the work would be stopped, and this has had the effect of him placing a larger force of men at work, and I think by # the time of my next report, both buildings will have been plastered.

I am making two trips a week to this Reserve, and all that it is possible to do, will be done to rush these buildings to completion.

Yours truly,

Remarks

1. The classroom, children's dining room and residence are all in great need of Kalsomine. I bought some myself last time to do the untidy parts in the house. We could do the house ourselves but it would be impossible for us to do the schoolroom and children's dining room. If the Kalsomine was provided I could get it done quite reasonably. In a work like this it is so necessary to have the surroundings as nice as possible.

2. There is no basement cistern here and it is impossible to haul more water than is needed for drinking and cooking purposes as over forty children especially can get away with a great deal of drinking water during a school day. Dishes, floors, towels, etc., and the washing of all hands at least once a day, are all very necessary. At present we only have the two wooden barrels for hauling water and two small tanks in the house. We manage during the winter by melting snow.
Sir:

I beg to forward herewith, requisition for school supplies from Miss Cunningham of the Little Pine Day school.

Miss Cunningham makes a hard try to keep her place in an exceptionally clean and tidy condition and if it was possible, I would ask the Department to allow her the faint and Kalsomine asked for.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the third instant, giving an estimate of the cost of the redecorating and repairs required at the Little Pines and Thunderchild Indian Day Schools.

The Department will approve of an expenditure of approximately $55.00 in decorating the school buildings and children's dining rooms at each of the schools.

Indian labour should be utilized as far as possible in having the above work carried out at these two day schools. While at Little Pine School last week, I took a notion to inspect the Heating Systems in the School and house and it is a marvel that these buildings ever survived last winter.

The furnace in the Residence has nearly half of the outer covering broke in and corroded through and the pipes were rusted through and fallen apart in several places and the grates were just warped rods.

The furnace in the school is worthless or not worth repairing.

To verify this, I took out M.A. Holiday, Steam fitter etc to check this a make an estimate of cost

The Residence Furnace would need grates 20.00
Repairs to casing and Pipes, including labor 55.00
Total 75.00

The school furnace will have to be discarded, a new one would cost about $350.00 and I doubt then if it would be much use as the cellar for it is too small and there is no way of getting registers except to one end, so I would recommend stoves, there is one wood heater there in good order.

One Furnacette would be required 70.00
8 Inch Galv pipe 30 feet Rivetted also 7 inch pipes cut in from 2 stoves, including installing 39.00
Total $109.00

To close off basement and trap door to Coal bin about $15.00.

This is a rather late date to apply for this, but as it was never reported to me I had no idea of the condition and it will certainly be needed before winter.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept of Indian affairs,
Ottawa.
EX'D.

Mr. S. L. Macdonald,
Indian Office,
Battleford, Sask.

Dear Sir,

This year we found it necessary to divide the schoolroom and use it for both junior and senior classes. The children's dining room has been used formerly for the juniors, but it was so cold last winter, and the teacher was kept so busy firing constantly, that the juniors were moved into the senior room and a curtain used for a partition. Under this arrangement the children were very nice and warm, but the noise was somewhat distracting to both classes. We would suggest, that when work is being done on the school buildings this year, a folding partition be built between the classes, and another outside door be made for the junior children.

Concerning Miss Stewart's departure, the enclosed speaks for itself. For the past two years I have been paying Miss Stewart's salary out of my own. Would it be possible for the Indian Department to provide a junior teacher's salary, or at least part of it? I would appreciate very much having my salary continued for the remaining time I shall be here. Miss Armitage, who is one of the most devoted Indian workers in the province, and is keenly interested in every phase of reserve life, never being off duty throughout the term, should have an increase in salary. Both church officials and reserve realize she is a valuable worker.

Yours truly,

H. L. Cunningham
I beg to forward attached letter from Miss A.E. Cunningham, for the Department's advice and would certainly recommend that her requests be considered, as this school is and always has been outstanding in Day schools and she has for the last several years paid a Junior teacher from her own salary and Miss Stewart just resigned was one of the best teachers we ever had and the regular Assistant, Miss Armitage is also outstanding, in fact they were a combination that were hard to beat.

With regard to the partition asked for, one as required would cost approximately $48.00 without painting and this could be done next year when the repainting of these buildings will be necessary. As to an extra outside entrance, this would require high outside steps and in my opinion not necessary in a building of this size, but the partition I would recommend, as also an increase for Miss Armitage and an allowance for a Junior Teacher.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Dr. Robertson,

Thank you for your letter of November 2nd. As you have asked, we can say from experience that the children could have rice pudding two or three times a week until the end of June, if four cases of milk were supplied. We think there is enough rice for this. Then as cocoa is very cheap, twenty-five pounds more would give them cocoa on alternate days. This with the regular soup and biscuit, would make a very nourishing meal.

I forgot to mention that the Farm Instructor supplies a certain amount of meat from the second week in November until Easter. The remaining months, I bought soup bones myself for the last few years, until last Easter (1937), when I was given permission to get $3.00 worth of soup bones per month at Paynton.

All this efficient thought for the reserve is most encouraging to both workers and Indians, especially as the last two or three years were unusually difficult.

Yours truly,

A.L. Cunningham.

Milk, 4 cases.
Cocoa, 25 lbs.
Dear Sir;-

Some time ago I visited the Little Pine Day School. In checking over the amount allowed for the mid-day meal I could not see how a good nourishing meal could be supplied. On questioning the teacher I found that she herself had been supplying some of the material. I asked her to submit a letter setting out what would be necessary in addition to what she was then receiving to furnish this meal up to the end of June. The attached letter is her reply.

I would recommend that authority be given to supply her with four cases of milk and 25 lbs of cocoa in addition to what she now receives.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir,

The excellent health this winter - due chiefly to the good noonday meal - has resulted in better attendance than that of last year; consequently we have used more cereal. Last spring I purchased 50 lbs. of pot barley myself, and we were supposed to be allowed that extra amount last fall. We should be glad to have 50 lbs. each of barley, rice and beans for the two and a half months after Easter.

Last year we were allowed $3.00 per month for soup bones from Easter to the end of June. May we count on the same amount this year?

You will remember that we received only forty seven boxes of biscuit last fall, instead of the usual seventy two. We probably have enough for the next two weeks, but need more for use immediately after the Easter holiday. Would you very kindly enquire about this?

We have proved the great value of the mid-day meal, so hope that there will be no difficulty in obtaining these supplies.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Do you expect the buildings will be painted this year, or shall I requisition paint as usual for the floors?

Dear Sir:

Per Department letter No.105-2-5, April 2nd, I might say, that the complete painting of the Little Pine School cannot be done for $200.00.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the Little Pine Indian day school on October 27 Public School Inspector A. R. Brown wrote, in part, as follows:

"I hope that something can be done to develop manual work for the boys. If there were a basement under the school it would make a fine workshop. The present farm foreman appears to be a good type to give the boys some carpentry and other shop practice if this could be arranged. I talked with him and found him interested."

Please let me know what you consider could be done to provide accommodation for giving the boys manual instruction. In replying you should furnish estimates of the cost of any work that you recommend.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

S. L. Macdonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.
Dear Sir:

I have Department letter No.105-2-5, Jan 7th, re Inspector Mr Brown and Manual training for boys at Little Pine Day School.

In this respect, I might say, that both at this school and the Red Pheasant Day school, we have long recognized the need of manual training, but till the last two years could never get any support for anything other than the routine courses, but with the support we have been getting for tools and equipment, there is already a showing at these two schools, but as Mr Brown states, space is wanted, we have already anticipated this and you will note that on my Estimates for next year, allowance is made for full basements at both the above schools, to allow for a good big room for manual training and also recreation, as both these schools are really overcrowded now. We have also recently sent a requisition for $10.00 lumber and small hardware for this purpose at Little Pine, Mr Warden our new Farmer at that Point and his Wife, who is a B.A. and Ex-High school teacher, take a great interest in the school and the above materials was requested so that during the present winter months, when his outside duties are not so heavy, he intends to teach the boys to make cupboards, doors etc. As this school has only Lady teachers, this kind of co-operation is appreciated, I might add, that Miss Armitage resigned last year was very handy with tools and carried on some of this work and her successor Miss Good, whose Father is Carpenter is also handy for a girl, so we are making some progress. Last spring, I sent the schools, each a booklet on Making Bird Houses, outside seats, trellis etc and they have made a very good attempt at copying them.

Mr Morgan, our Teacher at Red Pheasant, has also been using a lot of time in boy training, he has model Indian home plans and is trying to have every boy that leaves the school able to build one when starting on his own, Carpentry is his hobby and he is a handy mechanic in any way, is interested in the Indians and the school work and I might say, one of the best teachers we ever had.

At present none of this is possible at the Thunderchild Day School, but when a change is made, which I hope will be at the end of the present teaching year, that the Manual training be a condition, as, especially to the Indians it is the most useful training they can get.

I have written rather fully in this reply, to show that some progress is being made and we have most certainly had Dr Robertson's full support in all our efforts.

Your obedient servant,

Dept Mines & Resources,

Dear Sir:

Ref: Your #105-2-5 of April 26th, Improvements and Repairs, Little Pine School.

On a recent visit to Battleford, I discussed the matter of the conditions of the Little Pine and Red Pheasant schools with Mr. Macdonald, our Agent, and Dr. Lewis, our Medical Officer at that point.

The Little Pine School needs a basement and certain repairs, and the $900.00 appropriation could be used to good advantage at that point. They are, however, in much better condition than the Red Pheasant School. This school is badly overcrowded at the present time and a number of pupils have had to be turned away owing to lack of space. At the opening of the next session there will be at least 50 children who will want to attend that school, and there is no doubt that the Red Pheasant School should receive first attention.

At one time, I discussed with Mr. Macdonald the advisability of moving the school and residence to a more level piece of ground and to a point where water is available, as the water is a question at this point. When at Battleford recently, I asked Mr. Macdonald to take a contractor out to the school and ascertain in the first place if the buildings could be moved, and if so, the approximate cost. I also asked him to get figures on extending the school 20 feet, that is, making it 20 feet longer, and putting in a full basement.

I am now in receipt of a letter from Mr. Macdonald in which he states that he took a Mr. Wayman, a contractor, out to the school, and he reported that to move the residence would wreck it, as it is poorly braced and has plaster walls, consequently the idea of moving the buildings must be abandoned.

Mr. Wayman estimated that a 20-foot extension could be put on the

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
school, a full basement with an 8-foot ceiling, all cement walls and floor, would cost (for material) about $700.00. This would mean using Ten-test for the walls of the school, which he claims is cheaper and warmer than plaster.

A good wood-burning furnace would cost $250.00 and labour about $150.00, a total of about $1100.00. In explanation of the labour cost being so low, I might point out that the Indians have offered to do the excavating free for the privilege of using the basement as a Community Hall until such time as they can get a Hall of their own, and the work could be done largely by Indian carpenters with a white foreman.

You will note, in your letter of April 26th, that you state the appropriation for Little Pine is $900.00 and Thunderchild $125.00, a total of $1025.00, of which $75.00 has been spent for a cistern, leaving a balance of $950.00 for this work. The estimate for this work is therefore $150.00 above the appropriation, but in view of the necessity for this work, if it would be possible to find the money for it, I would strongly recommend that it be done.

In the meantime, I have advised Mr. Macdonald to make no further expenditure on Little Pine or Thunderchild schools until further advised.

With regard to the water situation, I would say that some time ago a well was dug to the depth of 30 feet, when they struck a stone. A small quantity of water is in this well, not sufficient for the purpose, but sufficient, I would say, to satisfy us that there would be no great difficulty in securing water at this point at a little greater depth.

I would also point out that Mr. Morgan, our teacher, as well as Mrs. Morgan, his wife, are carrying on splendid work at this school, both among the children and the women. I would place Little Pine, Red Pheasant and Sandy Lake as the first three day schools in the Province.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant regarding the repairs at the Little Pine Indian day school Mr. Gus Shrank of Paynton, Sask., may be engaged to supervise the work required.

Mr. Hoey is absent on holidays at the present time and on reviewing the file I cannot find any authority having been given to Mr. Ostrander to proceed with the repairs at Little Pine. The only letter on file that I have been able to locate is Mr. Hoey's letter to you dated May 31. Dear Sir:

On our return in the middle of August, we found that a serious epidemic of whooping-cough had developed on the reserve and it is only in the last week that we have felt assured that all the school children were recovering. They are all back to school now. The epidemic affected practically every family and in many cases, the women as well as the children. Three pre-school age children died, but we hope that now the worst is over.

Last year there was an abundance of berries, which were dried and stored for winter use and the people had plenty of vegetables also. This year, very unfortunately, there were no berries and no vegetables except potatoes. We were without Cod Liver Oil for four months and the lack of fruit and vegetables also has been hard on the children, who needed building up after the long sickness. For this reason we are asking for tomatoes to supply what is lacking in the present restricted diet.

Yours truly,

A.L.Cunningham.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, No. 105-2-5, in connection with voucher No. 462, re repairs at the Little Pine Day School.

In reply I have to say that purchasing regulations were complied with in this case, but that the authority of Department letter 105-2-5, dated 17th August, 1939, should have been quoted, instead of the authority as shown on the voucher.

The furnace at this school was useless, without being repaired, and I assumed that putting the furnace in condition to use, keeping within the total amount authorized for the completed job, would be considered a part of the program. The letter of authority for this work was quoted to me by Dr. Robertson as Departmental Letter 105-6-5, dated June 9th, 1939.

Dear Sir,

In the past has been the custom of the Department to engage a driver for the transportation of children to the Little Indian Day School during months of December, January, February and March at the rate of $2.00 per teaching day. Vouchers have been submitted and paid for these months.

I have to advise you that Miss A.L. Cunningham, the teacher took upon herself to continue the services of the driver for ten days during month of April, though I had informed her authority was only until March. She took the stand that as she had not used the full amount during December on account of the mild weather, she saw no reason why this credit could not be carried over until April. On account of so much water lying around the early part of April it was difficult for the children to reach school.

Miss Cunningham has guaranteed orders to the amount of $20.00, I advised her I would take the matter up with you to ascertain if you would consider paying for ten days during April, though I was doubtful if you would as she had definite instructions that authority ended March.

Yours truly,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant with reference to transporting children to the Red Pheasant and Little Pines Day Schools for a period during the coming winter.

The expenditure in this regard is charged under the heading "Travelling Expenses". This item of our appropriation has been very drastically reduced during the current year and consequently we have to curtail expenditure to the greatest possible extent.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter No. 105-2-5 of the 14th inst., the reason Voucher No. 464 was submitted for transportation of children to the Little Pine Indian Day School during month of December, 1940, was on account of the stormy weather we experienced during this month. I gave instructions to the teacher to use van as weather conditions warranted. Though on the distinct understanding that the amount allowed for January, February and March 1941 would not be exceeded if it was necessary to use van during December.

Regina, December 12th, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

LITTLE PINE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

I visited this institution on November 26th and there were twenty-four children present at the time of my inspection. On checking up the register I found that there were twenty-eight children on the roll and the teacher informed me that the average child there had to come about 2½ miles from his home to the school. He stated our Branch paid $60.00 a year for transporting the children to the school but this money only lasted about one month as they paid the man who supplied the conveyance $2.00 a day.

As you know, the teacher, the Reverend Alab Spence, is an Indian and personally I think he is doing very well. He is a nice sort of fellow and from what I gathered he is a good influence amongst the Indians there on the reserve and so is his wife. She is a daughter of Willie Bird of the Little Red River Reserve in the Carlton Agency.

The school needs interior decorating badly because it is far too dark but I suppose it will have to stay that way until next spring. They also need a new blackboard as the one there now is practically impossible to write on. The Public School Superintendent was there about a week before my visit to this school and the Reverend Mr. Spence told me he had made note of these things.

In conclusion, as I said above I was very pleased with Mr. Spence and his wife and I think they are capable and doing good work where they are and everything seems to be going along fairly well.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

When the Family Allowance Act goes into effect, no doubt we will have larger enrollments at the Day Schools. Will it be the policy of the department to continue providing supplies for the mid-day meal, or will same be discontinued, and for the parents of children attending school to provide lunches out of the money they will receive under the Act?

With the increased attendances the teachers will not be able to supervise the preparation of meals as has been the case in the past, without interfering with class work. We would also have to provide more cooking utensils, and perhaps engage help preparing meals and cleaning up.

Now would be the opportune time to advise parents they will have to assume the responsibility of providing lunches for children attending school. Teachers would be able to check lunch kits, and if suitable lunches were not furnished, we would then be able to take the question up with parents and insist that better food be provided. Failing to follow out instructions of either Teacher or Farming Instructor, a recommendation would then be made that allowances be discontinued.

I would be in favour of providing a hot drink of cocoa to pupils with their lunch, which would not be too much for the teacher to prepare.

C.S. Bell,
Acting Indian Agent.
Ottawa, May 2, 1945.

Mr. C. S. Bell, Acting Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.

I have your letter of the 24th ultimo, with regard to serving midday lunch at day schools in your agency during the academic year 1945-46.

I discussed the contents of your letter with the Acting Director, Mr. Hoey, and we feel it is reasonable to presume that when the family allowances are being paid the parents will provide better food at home for their children.

With this in mind, we believe that the midday lunch at any day school can be limited to special biscuits which the Department supplies, plus either cocoa or soup. The preparation of either of the latter would not involve any heavy work.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, November 5, 1945.

Mr. C. S. Bell, In charge of Indian Agency Office,
Battleford, Sask.

In checking the September quarter return,
of the Little Pine Indian Day School, it is noted that
the teacher states we have refused supplies for midday
meal purposes. This is not a fact, as we have already
ordered the nutritional biscuits, which I presume have
reached the school.

However, I reviewed our file and find
that on May 19 I wrote you a letter, acknowledging
receipt of a requisition which had just been received
for various supplies for the Little Pines School. While
we later purchased the paint and lumber, it now appears
that I neglected to authorize the following items:

1 wash board, 1 wash tub, 1 boiler,
10 bars of soap, 1 pane of glass, for front door,
1 pkg. tacks, 2 cases milk,
10 lbs. cocos, 50 lbs. sugar.

The Department is not discontinuing the provision of mid-
day meal supplies, but we are not increasing the amounts
allowed in previous years. It is reasonable to suppose
that with the payment of family allowances the Indian
children will be receiving better food and consequently
will not require so much at the noonday meal, or, if
they do, they will be able to bring it from home. In
the present case, it was simply an oversight.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

I have been reviewing the payments we have made in the last year for hauling water at the Little Pine School. Referring to your letter No. 105-2-5 of the 7th ultimo, re hauling water to Little Pine Indian Day School. On account of the higher wages now paid for such labour, Indians would not haul water for less than $6.00 per month. I have gone into the question why a well was not dug years ago. Two deep wells were sunk without finding water, and I am very doubtful if we engaged the services of a well digging outfit we would locate water now.

With reference to requisition of the 17th ultimo, the Department approves the following expenditures at the Little Pine Day School:

The approach of winter brings the problem of the school transportation on Little Pine Indian Reserve, for pupils. During the last ten years the people on Little Pine have moved so far from the Day School that it is now found necessary to have two sleighs and drivers instead of one. One driver picks up children east of the school and then has to cross the river for four families over there. The other driver gathers children from the west and south.

These trips would not be so long if the people lived in settlements but the houses are all scattered around the hills and valley, and the drivers must run a zig-zag course to reach all the homes, adding miles to their trips. This necessitates a very early start for them in the morning, and a late arrival home at night.

A boy of twelve lives across the river, four miles from the school. Boys of thirteen, twelve, eleven, nine and eight, and a girl of seven live across the river about three miles from school.

Down the valley, west of the school, live boys of eight and seven, with three miles to come. Another of seven has nearly two miles. South-west, with three and a half miles to walk are a girl of fourteen and two of seven. Within a mile radius of the school are about seven children from nine to twelve years. East of the school, with about one and three quarter miles to walk are boys of fourteen, nine and eight, and girls of thirteen, twelve and eleven.

Because of great distances to travel to reach the scattered homes, and the badly drifted trails which are hard on their horses, the drivers will not do the work for less than 75 cents a trip. This means $1.50 each, a day, or a total of $3.00 a teaching day.

At present thirty children, including one white boy, are attending school very regularly, and for the good of the children and the progress of the school I would like them to continue to attend. There are about twelve in school under nine years of age and I expect most of them would be most irregular in attendance after the snow.
the snow comes, because of roads, cold and distance.

Bad weather is usually from November till March, inclusive, and I feel if the transportation could be extended from the present period, to cover four months, November, December, January, February, that the attendance, so vital to any school would be very greatly improved on Little Pine Reserve. This would be roughly 75 teaching days, at $3.00 per day, or a total of $225.00 for the season.

I would strongly recommend that authority be granted to engage drivers to the amount of $225.00, as we have a first class teacher in Mrs. Sprague who should be given every encouragement in her work as teacher.

C.S.Bell,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, September 30th, 1947.

Mr. G.S. Bell, Indian Agent,
Battlesford, Sask.

We have your letter of the 23rd instant with reference to transportation of children on the Little Pine Reserve. Officials of various Departments of Education agree that children under ten years of age can walk two miles each way to school daily; pupils over ten years of age should be able to walk three miles daily each way.

The conditions may be more severe on your reserve and might justify transportation. The Department has decided to allow you the amount you request, namely $225.00.

However, we wish a very careful tally kept of the attendance so that you will be able to supply us with a report at the end of March next showing how many children attended school regularly as a result of providing transportation.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Little Pine Reserve,
Paynton, Sask.,
Mar. 27/48.

Col. B. F. Neary,
Dept. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I enclose a list of the children in Little Pine School and their attendance while school transportation was provided. The school was open for 74 days, and 25 children attended 60 days or more. Of the 37 on the roll, 5 have been in our school only since February when they came from Delmas Residential School. Two girls, 7 years old, living nearly 4 miles away, had the poorest attendance. The trails were so bad that the school sleigh could not get up the hill to their home and they could not walk to the sleigh which followed a
route 3/4 of a mile from their homes. Nearly all the other absences were from sickness.

February and March have been very cold and stormy, with deep and drifting snow, making the trail almost impassable. The attendance would have been very small on many days if transportation had not been provided. The drivers were very regular, and deserve great credit. The school and the people are very grateful for the increase in transportation allowance.

The allowance was for 75 days, but the closing for the Easter holidays made it 74, so probably there will be one day's driving in April.

I hope the good attendance we have had so far this year will not be lowered by the spring thaw. The valley down the middle of the Reserve becomes flooded. Last year children living across the Battle River
were absent 9 weeks during
the break-up of that year.

Yours truly,

M.A. Sprague.

(Mrs. M.M. Sprague).
Battleford, Sask.

C.S. Bell,

Honorable Sir,

I am informed that the Department is considering the advisability of establishing a day school at the Old Indian Reserve of Long Lake, for the benefit of a certain number of Indians going to settle there from Onion Lake Reserve. Allow me to make some few remarks on the subject.

I must say, from the start, that I am very little in favor of day schools for Indian children. From a long experience of over twenty years in this country, I must say that day schools for Indians have been, are and always will be, a complete failure. It is waste of time and money. This may not be perhaps a very great consideration for some; but what is more pitiable, it is waste of labor, of devotedness and of the best energies that it is in the power of men to consecrate on behalf of others. I have seen men and women devoting themselves, from day to day, and all through the long years, with exhibitions of self-denial which are above all pain, and the long-cherished hope of seeing, some day, the results of such efforts was never realized.

We may be sure that the result will not be different in the case of Onion Lake agency.

There are, on this Reserve, two Boarding Schools: one Catholic...
My other protestant. The Indians have full liberty in making their choice. They have the greatest opportunity of having a real education and permanent training given to their children.

The day school at Long Lake would be only a sham. At its best, it would still be very irregular. The labor spent on the children, for a few hours, on certain days, would amount to no permanent good. And, to say all my mind, if the Indians themselves claim for a day school, it is only to have a pretext not to put their children at the Boarding Schools. It seems to me that the Department should not give them such pretext.

The Long Lake Reserve is some twenty miles distant from the Onion Lake agency, where are the Boarding schools. It is a convenient distance for the parents to visit their children when they wish to do so. So that I consider that the Department has every reason not to establish a day school at Long Lake, if it is a question of guarding the true interests of the Indians themselves.

Pardon me for having expressed my mind so freely, because I have a decidedly settled opinion on the whole subject.

I have the honor to remain,

Honorable Sir,

Your most respectful & obedient servant,

+ Emile J. Legel, Bp. of St. Albert.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mr. Agent Sibbald writes the Department that the Indians of the Kesheewin reserve are anxious for the establishment of a day school and that they are not particular whether such school should be placed under the supervision of the Roman Catholics or the Church of England. The list inclosed with Mr. Sibbald's letter shows that there are about 17 children of school age on the reserve, and he thinks that if one were established it would be a success.

In connection with this matter the Roman Catholic Bishop of St. Albert has written the Department saying that he is very little in favour of day schools for Indian children and pointing out that one is not required on this reserve, as they can easily attend one of the boarding schools at Onion Lake, which is only twenty miles distant from the reserve and the parents could visit their children when they wished to do so.

I think the Bishop's reasons against the establishment of a school are entitled to consideration, and as there is no provision for a teacher or a school building and as the children could be placed in one of the boarding schools at Onion Lake, there does not appear to be any great necessity for acting on Mr. Sibbald's suggestion.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 20th ultimo, No. 304033, relating to a contemplated opening of a day school on Keeheewin's reserve, No. 123, I beg to report as follows:

During my last trip to the reserve I made a house to house visit and got full particulars with regard to the families and the ages of the children; since then I have drawn a map of the reserve which I enclose herewith. The location of the Indian houses will be found, with the owners names written alongside; also, in red ink, a figure indicating the number of children of school age belonging to that family. It will also be noticed that the map is divided into quarter sections, one half mile square, so that the distance that each child would have to travel to reach the proposed site of the school (also shown) can be readily judged. A few families of this band, No. 123, are not living on the reserve, but these with children will probably move on to it soon after the close of this winter.

There are 13 children belonging to this reserve already at school, viz.:
- 1 at High River Industrial School
- 1 at C. of E. Boarding School, Onion Lake
- 11 at R. C. Boarding School

and all the other children of school age are Catholics, the band being almost purely Roman Catholic. I also enclose a table classifying the children of school age, which may be found useful.

In connection with this reserve, I would inform you that within a few days the sawing into lumber of about 2000 logs will commence; the track is now being laid and
the saw and engine will soon be in position. It is likely that when the Indians have their lumber, they will take up new positions on the reserve and be more evenly distributed, so that the proposed position of the school would then be more convenient than it appears to be at present. I explained at each house, the department's proposition with regard to the school, and all with one exception welcomed the idea. Dear Sir,

I understand that it is proposed again to establish a day school on the Reserve of Keeyiwin, at Long Lake. Some few years ago when this question was first agitated, I volunteered to make some representations the justness of which was readily acknowledged and the project was abandoned. The conditions have not changed in the least since then. There is no reason whatever for a school at that point. I can predict a signal failure for such school, and an average of 4 or 5 pupils at most, for only a few months in the year, in spite of the noon meal and the hired team to bring the children to school.

This school without being of any usefulness would markedly injure the two Boarding schools at Ponoka Lake, because it would afford a pretext to the Indians for not sending their children to these schools.

The experiment of such Day schools has been made recently at Blackfoot Reserve, and I believe that one experiment of that kind should be sufficient for the Indian Department to come to the conclusion that Day schools are not and will not be, for a long time yet, adapted to the class of Indians of this country.

I beg that this letter be submitted to the Superintendent General for his personal consideration, and I remain,

The matter was left in abeyance because an enlargement to the reserve was contemplated, and it was wiser to wait until the Indians had become permanently settled.

Dear Mr. Leibald,

I understand that the Indians at Long Lake prefer sending their children to the Boarding Schools, because they always expect a day school to be organized at their own place. On the representations made by me to the Superintendent of Indian Affairs, I have been assured that no decision has been reached yet on that point, and I hope that the decision will be adverse to that plan. In my opinion our Indians are not prepared as yet, to avail themselves of the benefits of day schools, and it will be at least till several generations of the parents have been trained in the boarding schools.

The training in these Boarding Schools is certainly more easy, more satisfactory to the teachers, and more thorough for the children, and it would be a pity to deprive the Indian children of this training. As you may well know as well as myself, a day school here would be only a sham; the attention would be illusive and this school would stand there only as a pretense not to send the children to Boarding schools.

They have two Boarding schools to send their children attending to their faith. Let them profit by this splendid opportunity that so many white people envy to them. I think it would be good policy to try to make them understand that a day school would be rather a nuisance to them, and I would be very much grateful to you if you would kindly use your wide influence in that direction.

Dear Sir,

It is very kind of you to have kept me informed of the movement started again for the establishment of a Day School on Keechenu Reserve. I do not think that the conditions have been materially altered, in the least, since I sent my objections to the Department. They are the same now as they were some years ago. The day school would a perfect failure, and moreover a pretext for not sending the children to the Boarding School.

As the great majority of the Indians there are Catholic, it would be in order to engage a Catholic teacher for such day school, and for my part, I do not know of any one who could be induced to assume this most thankless of all tasks. So, I believe that the Indians should be clearly told that there is no hope for a day school on this Reserve, and that they must send their children to the Boarding Schools, if they really want them to be truly educated. It seems to me that it should not be too difficult to make them understand that these day schools amongst them have been tried, and always found to be utterly ineffective.

Therefore, I hope that the Department will agree with me and not allow any school to be built there until the time when it shall be advisable to build a new Boarding School on this Reserve, to take the place of the one now in operation.

And I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours very respectfully,

Archbishop of Edmonton.

Mr. Scott,

We have had no notice of any probability of the Indian wishing to take over the building, which is a log house, 16 feet by 18 feet. Sir,

With regard to the prospective reopening of the Day School on Kechewin's reserve I beg to report as follows.

The Department will remember that the Kechewin (Long Lake) Day School was closed prior to the Summer holiday owing to the resignation of the teacher, Frances Dion. When last at the reserve, on Sept. 20th, the Indians expressed a desire that the school be reopened. The building was soon reoccupied by the owner, an Indian, from whom it was rented but I do not anticipate that there would be any difficulty in getting the use of the building again should we be able to make use of it. I did not ascertain positively because the owner was absent, but one of the councillors informed me that he believed the Department could purchase the house for $100 or $120. He also said the owner has been drawing a rent of $5 per month at which rent I suppose we could get it again but I think it would be more advisable to purchase the building right out.

The greatest hindrance lay in being unable to secure a suitable teacher.
but now I believe a suitable man has been found. His name is James Kyatapew or Stonechild who has been living on Onion Lake for some time. He belongs to Sanson's band of Hoblins Agency and wishes to be transferred to this agency and has obtained the consent of Sanson's band to his leaving that land but so far the acceptance has not been signed by any of the bands of this agency. Onion Lake band is the one he wished to belong to in this agency but since the time of the influenza epidemic when he lost his mother and his daughter her husband, he has become unsettled. He speaks English well, writes well and expresses himself well when writing, and says he is equal to the work of teaching Indian children. His wife can speak a little English but has had no education but can sew and make clothes. He was educated at the Red Deer Industrial School and has a knowledge of tailoring and as he says himself she can be of much help to him. When he married he became a Roman Catholic and has been baptized in the Roman Catholic Church.

I have much pleasure in recommending James to the position of teacher and his wife to the position of sewing mistress. Both have been recommended by Rev. Father Thomas Principal of the Onion Lake Boarding School. The new teacher can live where the old one lived, in a building belonging to them to the church.

At present all the children of school age are either attending a day school on the reserve or are in residence at one of the Indian residential schools at Onion Lake. The Department has a day school in operation on each reserve with an enrolment of nine and twelve respectively, and it is quite obvious that recruits cannot be supplied to Blue Quills School without having a very serious effect on these and probably result in their closing. Dear Sirs:

I heard that there is talk of our little day school being shut down.

On behalf of the Keechewin's band of Indians, I wish to state that we are strongly opposed to the movement.

I do not see where anyone is going to benefit through the closing of this particular school.

The following are a few reasons why we wish to retain same:

1. The enrollment at the present time is too little once - about all of the children of school age there are on the reserve. At a meeting of the local women's institute a short time ago, it was resolved that they would never submit to their children being moved to a boarding school until such time as these children were able to look after themselves.

2. We feel that the day school is indispensable in that it gives the child a start at home and makes it much easier for him to accept the routine of the boarding school when the time comes for him to enter same.

3. The average child is naturally afraid to leave home and
begin his studies in a strange place, he has not the slightest idea of what to expect. The school teacher gradually消除 this fear from the child's mind and prepares him for the next step until he is more than willing and he is confident that he can take care of himself.

4 I do not see where the little beginner is going to receive the attention he requires when he first enters the boarding school where there are over one hundred other children demanding the teacher's supervision.

5 As we have no stores nor public places of any kind on this reserve, the school has played an important part as a gathering place for our young men and boys, especially during the long winter evenings. I have personally attended on two different occasions during the past winter and I found that besides being a diversion, these gatherings are educational as well and should be encouraged.

6 I am sure that the Dept. is as anxious as I am to see improvements on this reserve. I wish to state that the shutting down of the day school will be taking us several steps downward instead of up.

I want to ask the Department to consider very carefully before deciding to close our little school, knowing as I do that the welfare of the Indians depends on the encouragement given them in their various reserves.

Signed: Chief Gustave Dion

Cold Lake, Alta., Oct. 5, 1933

The Deputy Minister
of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

For quite a long time I intended to write this letter. It was delayed in the hope that a favorable solution would come for the question of the day school of the Sioux reserve at Keechewin or Long Lake Sioux Reserve, Alta.

It is not my habit of writing often to the Indian Department to complain but if I do today it is on account of my desire to accomplish my duty, and even to give a few precise points on the day school of the Onion Lake Indian Agency.

During the month of June last, order came from Ottawa to close the day schools of the Onion Lake Agency and on that account the school of Keechewin is closed since last June.

May I say, Sir, that the closing of that school of Keechewin is a calamity for that reserve, and I am well aware of the fact having been in charge of that reserve for a number of years. At this school there is a daily attendance of 10 to 12 pupils. The school master Mr. Francis Dion, an old pupil of the Indian school of Onion Lake, has given most satisfactory results during the 16 years he has taught. What I cannot understand is why the school of Frog Lake, Alta., in the same Agency of Onion Lake, remains open when there is not or hardly any children frequenting that day school. For several years there was a movement to close that day school, and when the order came to close the schools, we found that the one which should have been closed first remained opened, while the
others which were giving fair satisfaction remain closed. For the school at Frog Lake I know what I am talking about, for I was in charge of that reserve for a few years and I can say that the number of children attending that school is very limited. To sustain this assertion you can consult the reports of the federal and provincial inspectors. There is consequently bad influence somewhere. I have absolutely nothing against the school teacher at Frog Lake, but I feel it unjust that he should be maintained in his position and that his school be kept open while the others are closed. If he is employed as farm instructor, he should be paid as such and not as a teacher, and if he wants to teach school at his own free will and without pay, no one would have anything to say.

Consequently we should protest against that state of affairs. Furthermore His Grace the Bishop of Edmonton will protest against it officially.

A thing which does not seem comprehensible, is that the two Indian day schools under the direction of the Church of England at Frog Lake, Alta., and Little Island Lake, Sask., remained opened and in the same Indian Agency of Onion Lake, while our day schools of Keechewin and St. Geoff., Alta., remain closed. In the same way that Frog Lake, Sask., which was opened and supported by the initiative of private subscription, is not yet officially recognized by the Department.

These reserves of Keechewin and St. Geoff., are two reserves which are entirely catholic and we have as farm instructors protestants holding such positions.

Hence, I request that the day school of that reserve of Keechewin be immediately opened and placed under the direction of our nearest
teacher Mr. J. Francis Dion. There will be at least a dozen of children that will attend to it; because the Indians here are very anxious to have the school opened on their reserve as in the past.

If someone preaches economy in all the departments of the government, that economy should be applied with justice for everyone and not only for a few.

Hoping dear sir, that this letter will bring a favorable reply.

I subscribe myself

Yours devotedly,

(J.S.) J. E. Pratt, Trustee

O.M.D.
Ottawa, October 25, 1933.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, relative to the closing of the Long Lake Indian Day School, on the Kehiwin Reserve.

In reply I have to say that this school was closed on account of attendance. It is considered that the children of school age could be placed in the Blue Quills Indian Residential School, as there is ample accommodation for them and this school has had difficulty in recruiting up to its full number. Our funds this year were so limited, that it was necessary to close a number of day schools. The Frog Lake School was continued, owing to the fact that there was no accommodation for these children in the Onion Lake Anglican Indian Residential School. At the Cold Lake School, which has also been closed, there were very few Indian children, and these children can be placed in the Blue Quills School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. E. Pratt, O. M. I.,

Ottawa, November 9, 1934.

Sir:

I have to inform you that it has been decided to re-open the Leng Lake Indian Day School, on the Shiwun reserve, Onion Lake agency. Dr. Hill, Indian Agent, states there are 17 children of school age on the reserve, and, with this number enrolled, there should be an average attendance of at least 10.

Rev. Father U. Langlois, Provincial of the Oblate Order, under whose auspices the school will be conducted, has nominated Mr. Charles Hebert for the position of teacher. The Department is informing Dr. Hill of the approval granted for the re-opening of this school and for the appointment of Mr. Hebert as teacher. The salary allowed Mr. Hebert will be at the rate of $20 a teaching month. It is expected that this school will be opened in the very near future.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. Murison, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Regina, Sask.

No residence is furnished for the teacher, Mr. J. F. Dion, and he and his wife, who is employed as seamstress, and children are living in a small Indian house which they have borrowed for the purpose, and which is not at all suitable for them. The Indians of the band, being desirous of retaining the services of Mr. and Mrs. Dion, have taken out logs to erect a building which could be used as a schoolhouse; with the idea that the building now used for that purpose could be used as a residence for the teacher. This plan Mr. Dion assured me would be most acceptable and satisfactory so far as he and his family are concerned. The new building would be built close to the present schoolhouse and would be about 22 by 26 feet in size, and the Indians have offered to furnish the logs and lumber, and perform the labour, free; but have asked me to request the Department to supply shingles and tar paper for the roof, and doors and windows for the building; costing approximately $100.00 made up as follows:

OTTAWA, June 6th, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo regarding the erection by the Indians of a log building for school purposes on the Kecheewin's (Long Lake) Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that if the Indians undertake the work of putting up this building, the Department would be prepared to authorize an expenditure not exceeding $100 in the supplying of shingles, nails, tarpaper, doors, windows and hardware, as per your estimate. These supplies, however, only to be furnished when the walls of the building are erected, and the material asked for actually needed to complete the work. You are hereby authorized to purchase the above mentioned supplies at the time when you consider the work of putting up the building has sufficiently advanced to warrant the goods being delivered.

It will be necessary, in making the purchase, to obtain competitive prices as far as possible, and you should forward properly certified vouchers covering the expenditure incurred.

I have the honour to report that on several occasions during the past two years, Amahoose, an Indian from whom Department rents the building which is used for a Day School at Kesheewin's reserve; has asked me to request the Department to purchase it for the sum of $100.00. MR. SCOTT.

With reference to that portion of the letter of Chief Sam Waskawitch, forwarded by F. O. Loft, Toronto, regarding the school building at Long Lake, on the Keechewin's Reserve, Onion Lake Agency, No. 65, and the school at this point is at present being conducted in a building which the Department purchased from an Indian in July, 1922. Previous to that time rental was paid for this building at the rate of $5 per month. It was found that this building was unsatisfactory for classroom purposes, and the Indians agreed last winter to get out logs for the erection of a new school building. This they did, and the walls of this new building are now partly built. The Department has supplied shingles, window frames and doors, and the Indians themselves were to do the work in completing the building.

This matter could be taken up with the Indian Agent to ascertain definitely what amount of work the Indians have already performed in the erection of the building, and what further material, if any, in the way of interior finishing, such as flooring, nails, etc., is required. Mr. Inspector Murison, in a report dated March 3rd, last, on a visit to this school, stated that it was expected that the Indians would have the building completed by the end of March, 1923. We have no further information as to what has been done since the Inspector's visit. The building purchased, which is now used as a classroom, was to be fitted up as a residence for the teacher when the new school building was finished.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Although progress has been slow with this building it has not been neglected. The delay has been caused chiefly by the difficulty some of the Indians experienced in getting the necessary lumber. Sir,

I have the honour to refer to your letter of March 3rd, last, No. 115-5-5, in connection with a building for school purposes which the Indians of Keshewin's reserve were erecting; and to enclose herewith Vouchers No. 12 and 13 for payment of material purchased.

This school is now completed and a very nice substantial building has been put up. It is of logs, the inside measurements being 18' x 24', and is of two stories with a well shingled roof. The upper story is to be used as a dining room for the pupils for their midday meal and is entered by a flight of stairs running up from the outside, which leaves the whole of the ground floor space as a classroom.

The building of this school is a credit to the whole band. The Indians not only took out the logs and hewed them, but they also supplied the rough lumber required and did all the labour of building without pay. I complimented them upon this work and told them that I would try and have their new school properly equipped. I would therefore recommend that before the building is taken over for occupation it be supplied with desks. There are no desks in the old school building only two large tables and four forms. The number and kind of desks required are ten, medium size, double Preston desks. A teacher's desk and chair would also be very useful and would be much appreciated. It will be necessary also to purchase six blinds for the windows, and a broom, pail, dishpan, etc. These could be purchased locally at a cost not exceeding $10.00.

I may mention that it is intended to fix up the old schoolhouse as a teacher's residence. An amount of $100.00 was placed in Estimates for that purpose.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

You are authorized to expend the sum of $10 in the purchase of blinds for the windows, a broom, a pail and a dishpan. You are also authorized to prepare the old school house for a teacher's residence. The estimate of $100 for this purpose should not be exceeded, if possible. Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith Voucher No. 116, amounting to $74.10 in my favour, for labour in connection with the new Indian Day School, and alterations to the old one, at Kesheswin's reserve of this Agency.

The new Indian Day School was taken into use after the summer holidays and is a good building in every respect. A flight of stairs, outside, at the back of the building, lead to an upper floor over the classroom and it is in this upper room the midday meal is eaten. Most of the work on this building had been performed by the Indians free, but a little finishing work was required to be done, and this I agreed with Indian Solomon Youngheier, who is quite a handy carpenter, to pay for. Most of the time covered by the accompanying voucher is, however, for work on alterations to the old schoolhouse to make it suitable for a teacher's residence. There were ceiling joists in this old building but no flooring on them; flooring has now been put down and a stairway made leading to this upper room, the whole of which can now be used as sleeping quarters. Partitions have been put in on the ground floor and two suitable living rooms have been made. At my last visit to the reserve on October 7th, the work was not quite completed, but the teacher, Mr. J. F. Dion, expressed himself as being well satisfied with the work done, and I have no doubt he is now living in the building with his family.

It was necessary to install a stove drum to heat the upper floor of the Day School; this I instructed Mr. Stephenson, the Farm Instructor, to purchase locally and put in.

KERHEWINS DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this school on March the 6th and found 6 boys and 4 girls present out of an enrollment of 13. I found the health of the children was good at the time of my visit and they presented a clean appearance. Four wash basins are provided, as well as separate towels and they are also provided with toothbrushes. For recreation they have one swing, a tester, football and baseball. They also join in organized games under the direction of the teacher. The teacher's wife receives $15.00 per month for taking care of the school and looking after the cleanliness of the children. She also teaches them sewing and knitting. The teacher has a garden and provides the children with vegetable soup while the garden stuff lasts. The teacher also supplies milk to the children from his own cows and when milk is plentiful they boil their biscuits in it. There is no mid-day meal provided at this school. The only thing given by the Department are two biscuits per day for each child. Many of the people on this reserve are poor and there are times when the children have very little to eat at home. There is no doubt that the kindness of the teacher in supplementing their mid-day meal has added greatly to the attraction of the school for the children. Mr. Francis Dion, the teacher, is a graduate of the Onion Lake Residential School. He is very earnest in his work and has made a great effort to acquire a knowledge of teaching methods with a degree of success, which in my opinion reflects credit upon him. I found the buildings and premises in a clean and tidy condition. The comfort of the teachers dwelling has been added to by lining the house with V joint. The buildings are log and are plastered with mud, which, of course, washes off with the summer rains and entails considerable amount of work replastering each year. If this
mud were replaced with lime and sand, it would be much more satisfactory. It is difficult to keep the children at this school after they reach the age of twelve years and the people are being encouraged to send their older children to residential schools.

INSPECTION REPORT ON SCHOOLS ONION LAKE AGENCY

Dear Mr. Graham,

I visited this school on October 31st and found 4 boys and 2 girls present out of an enrollment of 10. The teacher's 3 girls were also present. They are attending the school, but are not shown on the register.

Mr. Francis Dion, the teacher, continues to be quite faithful to his duties, and I considered his work quite commendable, considering the disadvantages that he has to work with, particularly insofar as the irregularity of the attendance is concerned.

The children were quite clean and tidy and healthy looking.

The school building was also clean and presented a good appearance. Since my last visit this building has been plastered with lime and sand and whitewashed. Only the school was re-plastered with lime and sand. When I suggested the re-plastering of these buildings in my last report, I included the teacher's residence, but the agent apparently was under the impression that only the school building was to be done. I think that the teacher's residence should be re-plastered with lime and sand. It is a difficult matter, where they live in houses the year around, to keep them looking decent. These buildings would look better if the roof and the gable ends were painted. The outside closets should also be painted. The teacher has asked for doorsteps in front of the school. These might be supplied and also 1 large and 1 small iron gate for the fence.

A new well is also required at this school. The present well does not furnish an adequate supply for the use of the school and teacher's residence.

The teacher also asks if he might be provided with pictures of the King and Queen and some other prominent men as well. We have pictures of the King and Queen in practically all of our schools and I would recommend that the Department supply these.

W. Murison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Commissioners Office, Regina, Sask.
