Sir:

Mr. Inspector Murison, in a report on his recent inspection of the Long Lake Indian Day School, states as follows regarding the building:

"The school building was clean and presented a good appearance. Since my last visit this building has been plastered with lime and sand and whitewashed. Only the school was replastered with lime and sand. When I suggested the replastering of these buildings in my last report, I included the teacher's residence, but the Agent apparently was under the impression that only the school building was to be done. I think that the teacher's residence should be replastered with lime and sand. It is a difficult matter, where they live in houses the year around, to keep them looking decent. These buildings would look better if the roof and gable ends were painted. The outside closets should also be painted. The teacher has asked for doorsteps in front of the school. These might be supplied and also one large and one small gate, iron, for the fence. A new well is also required at this school. The present well does not furnish an adequate supply for the use of the school and teacher's residence."

It is, no doubt, too late this season to have the work recommended by the Inspector carried out, but you should draw the various matters referred to by the Inspector to the attention of the Department early next spring. You should give an estimate of the cost of the labour and material required in having the teacher's residence replastered with lime and sand, also in having the roof and gable ends and outside closets painted, and in having doorsteps installed in front of the school. You should also state the cost of supplying a large and a small iron gate for the fence.

You will note what the Inspector states regarding the well. You might, when giving information regarding the buildings, also furnish a report as to what steps you would recommend be carried out in providing an adequate supply of water at this school and the cost of same.

In the meantime, it is hoped that conditions will be satisfactory for the carrying on of the work and that the teacher and pupils will be comfortable during the present winter.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

I have the honour to refer to the last paragraph of your letter of March 26th, last, No. 115-5-5, with respect to a well for the Long Lake Indian Day School at this Agency.

I had heard of a man with a well boring outfit at Heinsburg, a small town situated to the south of, and between, the Frog Lake and Long Lake Indian Reserves; so, on the 27th instant, I visited him and obtained his prices for boring a well two feet in diameter. These are $2.25 per foot for the first 20 feet with an increase of 25¢ per foot for every additional 20 feet. At this rate, and estimating the depth of the well at 75 feet, the cost would be $195.00; which, together with the cost of the cribbing, $30.00, would bring the total cost to $225.00. I do not think it will be found necessary to go so deep as 75 feet for water, but thought it safer to estimate at that depth.

If the Department decides to authorize me to have this well made for the Long Lake School, it might be well to consider having one made at the same time for the Frog Lake Day School. This school has never had an adequate water supply, although several shallow wells have been dug there. I believe that the cost of a well for this school would be, approximately, the same as that for the Long Lake School.

I have the honour to be

Ottawa, May 8th, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, giving an estimate of the cost of boring a well for the use of the Long Lake Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of your arranging for the well boring outfit mentioned by you to bore a well at this school. We note that the approximate cost, including cribbing, will be approximately $225, depending on the depth to which the well will have to be bored. You may also arrange for the purchase and installation of a pump of a suitable type, if same is required, and you should see that the well is satisfactorily completed in all respects and that there is an ample supply of water for school use.

Relative to the boring of a well by the same outfit, and at the same cost, at the Frog Lake Indian Day School, I have to say that the Department will also approve of your arranging to have a well bored at this school. It is hoped that it will not be necessary to expend any larger amount in having the work done at this school than at the Long Lake School. You may also arrange for the purchase and installation of a pump, if same is required.

The Department will leave the matter of having the wells satisfactorily completed at both the above schools in your hands to have the work carried out at the least possible expense, and after these wells have been bored, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred for each school separately.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith Voucher No. 255, amounting to $239.25, for a well for the Long Lake Indian Day school; and also a letter which Mr. Warne, the farming instructor at that reserve, has sent me with reference to having a well drilled at the farmhouse there.

Some seven or eight years ago a well was bored at the Long Lake farm, and the water was good for some time, but afterwards became very alkali, and is still so and cannot be used. This well also is 75 feet deep, and experience with this and other wells in the district has proved to us that the alkali comes into the well about 40 feet from the surface and runs into the good water, which is deeper, and spoils it; and it seems that the only way to overcome this difficulty is to have a well drilled, like the one just completed at the school, and drive an iron casing past the alkali, thus shutting it off, down into the good water which lies at a depth of about 75 feet.

If the Department consents to allow me to have a well made at the farmhouse, I would ask it to kindly wire me, as the outfit is being left on the reserve for the present. I may add that if I had known of the success which we would have in obtaining water at the school on this reserve, I would have placed an item in my estimates to cover the cost of a well for the farmhouse.

I should add that the cost of drilling this well will be, approximately, the same as at the school.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,

Inspector Murison's Report on Schools in the Onion Lake Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the three day schools and two residential schools in the Onion Lake Agency which I visited recently. I will report on these schools in the order of their visitations.

LONG LAKE DAY SCHOOL.

This school is situated on the Keeheewin Reserve. The classroom is a 1½ story log building, and is quite well adapted for its purpose. It is roomy and well lighted, and I found it in a cleanly condition. There are 5 boys and 5 girls enrolled, 8 of whom were present on the day of my visit. The average attendance is 5.

I found the children clean and healthy looking. Three wash basins and individual towels are provided in the classroom. A mid-day meal, consisting of soup and biscuits, is given the children. This is prepared by the teacher's wife who also gives them instruction in knitting and sewing. The children are also given instruction in gardening during the summer. For recreation they have a football and a teeter, which is also used as a merry-go-round.

They have a good well 24 ft. deep with an ample supply of excellent water. The teacher asked W. M. Graham, Esq., Indian Commissioner, Regina, Sask., if he...
LONG LAKE DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

if he might be provided with a wooden pump as his present iron pump head freezes up in winter. I pointed out that all that is necessary will be the wooden pump head, which is an inexpensive matter.

The teacher, Francis Dion, is an ex-pupil of the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School. He is a man of good habits and is earnest in his work. The trouble at day schools on outlying reserves, where the Indians devote a great deal of their time to hunting and trapping, is the intermittent attendance, and it cannot be expected that a teacher, not matter how well qualified, could get satisfactory results under those conditions.

I found the premises in a tidy condition, and the fence in good repair.

Inspector Murison's Report on Schools in the Onion Lake Agency

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report of a visit I made to the Residential and Day Schools in the Onion Lake Agency during the month of October last.

LONG LAKE DAY SCHOOL

I visited this school on the 7th March last and again on the 18th of October. On both occasions I found the school in a clean and tidy condition. The children were well clothed and presented a clean and healthy appearance. On my last visit I found five boys and four girls in attendance, their ages ranging from five to eight and one half years. As the Indians of this Band still follow their avocation of hunting and trapping in season as a means of livelihood, the attendance varies; the average attendance during the cold winter months being better than during the fall. In February last the average attendance was eight. In October it was 4.84. Apart from the classroom work, the girls are taught knitting and sewing by the teacher's wife.

A garden, comprising one and one half acres of land, is kept in good condition and the boys assist with the work of weeding etc. during the summer months. During the winter months the children are given a hot bowl of vegetable soup; the produce of the garden being utilized in this way. In my opinion, providing this soup is a valuable feature in maintaining the health -

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
maintaining the health of the children. They have in addition two biscuits each. The cost of providing the small quantity of meat required for the soup is very low and I feel that the soup is of much greater value to the children than other hot drinks which have been suggested, such as cocoa, milk etc. I was informed by one of our Day School teachers that when the children return from their summer vacation, many of them are found with skin infections and after a few weeks at school, receiving a large bowl of hot soup daily, their skin clears up and their health improves. Indians, as a rule, are not vegetable eaters and the only vegetables that many of these children get regularly are what they get at the school in their soup. I can remember very well that when the question of supplying a hot drink for the children during the winter months was first suggested, the intention was simply to provide a hot bowl of soup to supplement the biscuits during the cold weather; but this privilege was taken advantage of at many points and a full mid-day meal provided requiring the services of additional help. It is not my idea to provide a mid-day meal, but I certainly would recommend that where a hot drink is being provided for the children, soup would be much more valuable and beneficial to the children than cocoa or tea, and the cost is very little, if any, greater. The vegetables required can be raised at the school, so the only cost entailed would be some cheap joints of meat. This can be obtained very cheaply at the present time.

The Teacher, Mr. Francis Dion, is an ex-pupil of the Onion Lake R. C. Residential School. The Provincial School Inspectors have taken an interest in this man and have given him valuable instruction which he has taken advantage of and they speak quite favorably regarding his work. He is a good influence on the Reserve.

- A women's circle -
A women's circle has been formed and meetings are held weekly in the upstairs room at the school, which are supervised by the Farming Instructor's and Teacher's wives. This brings the women together. They engage at sewing and knitting. This is having a good effect on the social life of the Reserve and tends to increase the interest taken in the manner in which they keep their homes.

W. Morrison

Extract from Inspector Swan's report on the Long Lake Indian Day School dated April 25, 1941.

Equipment The school should be provided with a flag. The toilets are much too close to one another and to the school, and their entrances are not screened in any manner. The classroom needs window curtains, a washstand and additional wash-basins. The school well is in need of repair; this important matter should receive immediate attention.
Ottawa,
May 15, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I attach the following extract from Inspector Swan's report in connection with his visit to the Long Lake Indian Day School on the 25th ultimo:

"The toilets are much too close to one another and to the school, and their entrances are not screened in any manner. The classroom needs window curtains, a washstand and additional wash basins. The school well is in need of repair; this important matter should receive immediate attention."

Please let me know the approximate cost of carrying out the Inspector's suggestions.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I visited the Day School on the Kihiwin Reserve a week ago today. As it was Saturday, there were no children in attendance but I had a talk with Mr. Dion, the teacher. This school is a log building of ancient variety. It must soon be replaced by a better structure, though I don't think it has to be anything fancy to get the required results.

I have just had a long discussion with Major Clark concerning the erection of these two schools. As the season will evidently be late by the time the supplementary estimates are brought down in the house, I would appreciate your comment on the following proposals:

1. That funds be transferred from other projects to enable the erection of the new schools required at Frog Lake and Long Lake.

2. That these schools be erected in accordance with plan 888 and that they be advertised jointly so that contractors can bid on both projects. We have found elsewhere that we were able to receive tenders much lower than when we only advertised one project.

3. That the site of the Frog Lake school should be on the property previously viewed by Mr. Clark and Mr. Taylor.

4. That the Long Lake school site be carefully investigated. The present school does not seem to serve more than half the available pupils and there is some difficulty due to the water.
Would it be possible to have a map made of the Reserve indicating the number of children of school age so that we can select a proper site for the school based on present and future needs.

I am sending a copy of this letter directly to Mr. Taylor so that you will be able to contact him directly concerning the points raised in this letter. If you can have an army message sent to me by August 12th, we can arrange to advertise for tenders.

Bernard F. Neary,

He replied and stated that plan 868 would be suitable at Long Lake and Frog Lake except that at the latter the teacher's residence might not be needed. Re: Long Lake Indian Day School.

Reference your 613-5(E), & 607-5, of the 5th instant to Mr. Gooderham, I beg to submit for your information a map of the Long Lake Indian Reserve, giving family locations, the present location of the Day School, and my recommendation for the new School sight. It will be noted on the map that a good many of the families have been living on that side of the Reserve near Muriel Lake, but the younger families are now scattering over the Reserve as farming is progressing each year, and I feel if the School is more centralized this will keep the Indians from congesting in one area. The homes towards the West and South sides of the Reserve are new (built within the past four years).

Also attached is a list of the parents, School Children, their ages, Religion, and the Grades attained. There are a few of these children attending the Blue Quills Indian Residential School.

There is only one draw back to the proposed sight, and that is water. It is very easy to get a well on this Reserve, but the water is not fit for drinking. At the present school sight there is no immediate supply of water, and I feel the further west on the Reserve we put the School, the better chance we have of getting good water.

In view of the fact that there are only two main roads across the Reserve, I do not feel that it will be any great difficulty for children to travel a distance of three miles across country. Our better farmers on this Reserve live on the West and South east side of this Reserve.

W. K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

I am informed by Mr. Taylor that the Saddle Lake well-boring machine found water at 31 ft. on the site of the proposed new day school at Long Lake. It is expected that he will have sufficient funds remaining in the accountable advance for the well at Goodfish to meet all or most of the costs of the well at Long Lake. This well will be used for the Assistant Agent's residence and in this way we can have the residence and the day school conveniently located side by side in the centre of the reserve. Re: Proposed new Day School, Kesheewin Reserve.

Reference your letter of even file dated Oct. 1st., regarding water supply, and technical advice in the operation of a pressure system at the new wells on the Long Lake Reserve, I wish to advise as follows:

(1) Well No.1 proposed for the School is 31 feet in depth with approximately 9 feet of water. This well can be dried but will be back to the approximate 9 foot level in three hours. The St. Paul Foundry have advised me that this supply is more than sufficient to operate a pressure system for a Day School and teacher's residence. Their figures for the usage by a family of five, is 40 gals. per day per person and it is not likely that more than 40 gals. will be used in one day by Day School pupils.

(2) Well No.2 proposed for Agency use is 29 feet deep with water rising approximately 8 feet. This well can be put down to within 3 feet of the bottom but it has not been possible to drain it. According to the St. Paul Foundry this well should be suitable for more than domestic use. I have also been advised, by the St. Paul Foundry, that, as long as there is 1 foot of water in the well, a pressure system can be used.

W.K. Taylor,
Superintendent.

My dear Lord Bishop,

As you know, the Indians on the Little Red River (New) Reserve have been asking for a day school for a number of years. I believe the time has now arrived when the school could be carried on with a reasonable attendance. There are 11 Treaty Indian children, belonging to four families, already of school age, living on the Reserve, at the present time; also one half-breed child and two white families, making in all 7 non-Treaty children of school age. There are also several younger children who will reach school age in the next few years. These children are feeling quite discouraged at not having a school, as the children are growing up without education, and a school has been promised for a number of years. Another factor in the situation is the creation of the National Park which takes away so much of the hunting and fishing.
grounds of the Montreal Lake Indians. These people cannot now make a living in the neighborhood of their old Reserve where the Church & School are situated. They are faced with the choice of settling on the New Reserve or farming, or going further afield for employment. If they come to the New Reserve, there is no chance of getting their children educated. But, the Residential schools at Lac la Rose, or Oka, have an effect already with children living nearer to these Reserves. If these people are to be encouraged to settle down and engage in farming, they ought to have the opportunity of having their children educated. A day school on the New Reserve would give them the opportunity that they desire so much.

I consider that a Day School with a good teacher, perhaps a married man whose wife could look after the sick, dispense medicines, would be of untold benefit to these people, contributing greatly to their moral and physical welfare.

Hoping that your own efforts, those of the Indian Department will result in the building of a school as soon as possible,

I am,
Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr Scott,

I am enclosing to you a letter from the Ven Archdeacon Paul, who has taken Archdeacon McKay's place in the Indian work of this Diocese.

This matter of Montreal Lake and the New Reserve has been up a number of times and it seems to me that the time is ripe to begin in earnest in the New Reserve.

The establishment of the National Park north of Prince Albert and stretching all round Montreal Lake Reserve is rapidly making the position of the Indians there untenable.

They are already beginning to discuss their next move and it seems to me that every inducement should be held out to them to select the "farming" alternative rather than going up to the North end of Montreal Lake to continue "hunting".

If a good school, just as they have been promised a good many times, according to their view of the matter, were planted at the New Reserve at once it would be a great inducement to draw them from the North of Montreal Lake suggestion down to the New Reserve to start farming and gradually drop the hunting.

The two White families mentioned are hedged in between the Reserve and the border of the National Park and will never have a school of their own.

I sincerely hope that a good Day school will be given to the New Reserve in good time before the people at Montreal Lake begin moving to the North end.

Not qualified under Provincial regulations.

Health: apparently good.

Success: Fairly satisfactory.

I was sorry to again find Mr. Shaw untidy in person. I suppose there is some excuse in the fact that he has but one arm.

I believe that he is interested in his work and sincere but he does not fall into the ways of public school teachers as readily as the teachers of the other Indian schools I visit. In spite of the peculiar organization of exercises and considerable disorder, the learning process appears to be fairly fertile.
LITTLE RED RIVER INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (Anglican)

I visited this school on the afternoon of October 24th, and found 4 Indian boys and 9 girls in attendance, out of an enrolment of 17. There are also 9 white children from the settlement surrounding the reserve enrolled. The children looked healthy and well nourished. The average attendance for the month was a little over 10.

Mr. Henry M. Shaw has been teaching at Indian day schools for many years and I consider that he is doing satisfactory work at this school. Both he and his wife are looked up to by, and have a good influence with the Indians on the reserve.

Since my last visit a fence consisting of page wire on tamarac posts with a toprail has been erected around the school premises. A small addition has been made to the cottage, which is greatly appreciated, and a frame stable has been erected. The stable has not been painted.

The school is situated on an 80 acre plot of land and some of the Indians told me that it was the intention of the Band to leave this block of land for the use of the school. A small pasture of say about 40 acres is required for the teacher's horses and cow during the summer months. As Mrs. Shaw acts as Field Matron, it is necessary that she visit the Indian homes and they require horses for this purpose.

There has been considerable work done towards improving the premises since my last visit and I am sure that Mr. Shaw will continue to improve the appearance of the premises. Everything seems to be running very smoothly at this school.

I regret to report Mrs. George Halkett, No. 101 of the William Charles Band, and three of her children suffered burns on the evening of the 22nd. Mrs. Halkett and the children were trapped near their home, they made several unsuccessful attempts to break through and finally returned to their home. Mrs. Halkett reports two of her children became panicky and ran out into the fire blazing two hundred yards away. It was at this time, effecting their rescue, that Mrs. Halkett was seriously burned and the two children slightly less seriously. It seems after this Mrs. Halkett and her children again returned to their home to await their fate.

I regret to report that several Indians belonging to the Little Red River Reserve who were working on that particular front, knew or suspected the Halkett's were trapped, but made no effective effort to help them or report their fate until Mr. Hino Pringnitz, husband of the teacher on the Little Red River Reserve, an employee of the Prince Albert National Park, who, on seeing the smoke, proceeded to the Reserve and arrived at the fire line near the point where the Halketts were trapped. The Indians informed Mr. Pringnitz that they believed Mrs. Halkett and her children were trapped.

Mr. Pringnitz together with his thirteen year old son drove his truck through the fire in the direction of the Halkett home. On his first attempt the smoke was so dense, he did not locate the home. On his second attempt he located the house, found the occupants laying on the floor in a semi-conscious condition and effected their rescue. The Indians did not accompany Mr. Pringnitz into the blaze.

Dr. McFadyen, our Medical Officer, reports Mrs. Halkett's condition is still serious, the children it is pleasing to report are recovering quite favourably.

On the 24th it was deemed advisable to vacate the children and aged from the Reserve. Mrs. Pringnitz, our teacher, accompanied the children and remained in charge until the danger had passed. Throughout, Mr. and Mrs. Pringnitz proved themselves to be very competent people.

(Sgd) E.S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency

Ottawa, May 12, 1928.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 5th instant, furnishing particulars as to the number of Indian and other children who could attend if a school and teacher's residence is erected on the new Little Red River Reserve, No. 106A.

In this connection I beg to inform you that Mr. Commissioner Graham will be authorized to arrange for the erection of the teacher's residence and classroom during the coming summer. We note that there are approximately 19 children and a number of children of settlers in the vicinity who could attend.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, May 31, 1928.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department has had considerable correspondence with the Bishop of Saskatchewan, Mr. Indian Agent Weir and others, with reference to a combined school and teacher's residence for the Little Red River Reserve No. 106A. It has been decided that such a building should be erected this year, and I have to authorize you to make the necessary arrangements at your earliest convenience. $4,000 is available for this combined classroom and teacher's residence. Please be guided by general instructions in the Deputy Superintendent General's l-1-5 of the 28th instant.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd ultimo, enclosing a list of furnishings and school supplies required for the Little Red River Day School and teacher's residence.

In reply I have to inform you that a requisition covering the classroom supplies is being sent to the Government Stationery Office. The supplies will be forwarded addressed o/c Mr. William A. Bear, Prince Albert, Sask., and will be marked "For Little Red River School".

The Department is obtaining prices for the supplying of the school desks, teacher's desk and chairs required, and you will be informed later when the order has been placed.

Relative to the other supplies and furnishings required, I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and forwarding of the following: 1 box stove for school, 1 cook stove for teacher's residence. These stoves should be of a type and size that would be satisfactory.

You may also arrange for the purchase of the following for the use of the school building: 1 water cooler, 24 enamel cups, 24 coat hooks, 12 yards towelling, and the following for the use of the teacher's residence: 1 sink, 1 sink pipe, 6 window shades of the sizes required and 36 heavy coat hooks.

You should endeavour to obtain all the above supplies as cheaply as possible, having in view the supplying of serviceable articles.

You should obtain itemized accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost of the above supplies. These you should certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment.

LITTLE RED RIVER DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this school on March 6th. It is under the auspices of the Anglican Church and was opened on February 13th. 12 Indian and 9 white children are enrolled. The average attendance of Indian children for the two weeks previous to my visit was 12, being the full number enrolled.

The Indians expressed satisfaction in being provided with this school and there appears to be evidence that it will be a going concern. I am told that the Indians from the north have expressed their intention of coming down in the near future and if they do, it may be only a short time until this school will be filled to its capacity with Indian children.

The children looked clean and healthy and were warmly clad. They bring their own lunches. The teacher asked if he might be supplied with biscuits and also Drimilk to enable him to give them a warm drink at mid-day. He stated that he does not want to institute the giving of a mid-day meal.

Mr. H. M. Shaw, the teacher, was transferred from Sturgeon Lake, and his wife has been retained at half her former salary as Field Matron and is now paid as assistant teacher. Her work, however, will largely be in the homes on the reserve.

It was noted that there was no towelling or tooth brushes provided.

This school
LITTLE RED RIVER DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

This school is a new frame building 22x30 with 2 front entrances and cloakrooms. It is lighted with four large windows at the north side and heated with a stove. The interior walls are lathed, plastered and wainscotted. It is furnished with 30 single desks and is a very neat and comfortable school building.

The teacher's residence is a small cottage divided into a kitchen, dining room and two bedrooms. There are no porches. A summer kitchen should be added as the cottage will be very hot during the warm weather. A stable has been authorized and the Agent was making arrangements for building it at the time of my visit. Good water has been obtained at a depth of 34 ft. Material for a fence to enclose the school buildings is required, and also wire and posts to provide a pasture for the teacher's driving horses and cow.

W. Murray,
Inspector of Indian Affairs.
Regina, Sask., April 15, 1929.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to submit herewith Inspector Murison's report on the various schools in the Carlton Agency.

Conditions at the Little Red River Day School appear to be satisfactory. I note that the teacher's residence is a small cottage divided into a kitchen, dining-room and two bedrooms, and that there are no porches. There is nothing in the Estimates to provide for a summer kitchen, and I should have thought it necessary. I think we should allow $75.00 for a fence to enclose the school and make a small pasture for the teacher's driving horses.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The buildings (schoolhouse and residence) are new. They appear to be substantially built. It is to be regretted that the school does not conform to our regulations in Saskatchewan as to orientation of light. The only light in the classroom comes from the north. It is sufficient except on a dark day such as the day of my visit, when the south side of the room was quite insufficiently lighted. It would have been quite as easy to get light from the west. The same floor space might have been had in a longer and narrower room, which would have been much better lighted and easier to supervise. It is too bad that a nice new school should be built this way.

I would like to see a flag pole with a flag flying each school day.
Ottawa, July 13, 1929.

Sir:

The building is in satisfactory shape on
the whole. Some repairs are needed, which I discussed

Ottawa, January 16, 1931.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection, in December, last, of the Little Red River Indian Day School, states that nothing has been done to improve the play space for the pupils or to provide play equipment. When weather conditions permit next spring, you may arrange to have sufficient ground around the school cleared and levelled for playgrounds for the children. It is not intended, however, that any large expense be incurred for this purpose. The Department would also supply some playground equipment, such as a football, indoor baseballs and bats, upon receipt of a requisition early next spring.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

John Weir, Esq.,

Ottawa, January 21, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, enclosing a requisition from the teacher of the Little Red River Indian Day School for classroom supplies, and requesting that repairs be made to the school well.

In reply I have to say that an order is being forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to send to the teacher's address the classroom supplies considered necessary.

Relative to the repairs and cleaning of the school well, I have to say that you may arrange to have this well cleaned out and placed in a good state of repair as soon as weather conditions permit. It is noted that the cost will be approximately $25. You should see that a satisfactory job is performed, and after the work has been completed you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

February 25th, 1931.

Sir,

On January 21st, 1931 letter No. 107-4-5 you granted authority to have the Little Red River Day School well repaired at an approximate cost of $25.00. I find that the cost of repairing well will be more than I had anticipated. I have already spend about $10.00 on the well and have got into blue clay. I am afraid on account of the nature of the ground we will have to go a considerable depth before striking water. Local prices for a well boring outfit are as follows:

$1.25 per foot for first twenty feet and an increase of twenty-five cents per foot for each ten feet.

However, I am sure I could get work done cheaper by engaging men at twenty-five cents per hour at this period of year. As it is essential to have water at school will it be in order for me to proceed with work keeping expenditure as low as possible?

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

John Weir

Ottawa, March 5, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, regarding the cost of carrying out repairs, etc., to the well at the Little Red River Indian Day School. It is noted that difficulty has been met in deepening the well and that the cost will be more than anticipated by you.

As it is essential to have water at this school, it will be in order for you to proceed with the work of deepening the well sufficient to obtain a good supply of water, but you should keep all expenditure for the purpose as low as possible. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to make the best arrangements possible to have the work done at the lowest cost. After the work has been completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

Little Red River Day School

I visited this school on the 17th February. The school was not open that day, being Sunday. I met all the people at the Church and later went on to the school where I had lunch and noted condition of the buildings and made enquiry into matters in general in connection with the school. I found the school building, although a comparatively new building, in very poor condition. The interior walls need replastering and both the interior and exterior of the building requires repainting, as well as some repairs to the woodwork.

The walls in the interior of the teacher's cottage are badly in need of redecorating and the exterior of the building should be repainted. I was not at all satisfied with the condition of the buildings and premises. They were not kept as neatly as they should have been.
Ottawa, March 8, 1935.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Murison, who visited the Little Red River Indian Day School on the 17th ultimo, reports on the condition of the building at that point. He states that he found this building, although comparatively new, in very poor condition. He recommends that the interior walls be replastered, that both the interior and exterior be repainted and that some repairs be made to the woodwork.

Regarding the teacher's cottage, Mr. Murison states that the interior walls are badly in need of redecorating and that the exterior of the building should be repainted. Further, he states he is not satisfied with the condition of the buildings and premises, as they are not being kept as neat as should have been done.

Certain funds will be available during the coming fiscal year for repairs and improvements to day school buildings. I would request that you submit a report, stating in detail the repairs and renovations which you would recommend be carried out at this school during the coming summer. You should give the approximate cost of each item. We would be prepared to favourably consider any decorating required to the interior of the building but, unless the expense is small, it is doubtful if any exterior painting could be authorized. When we have your report as to the work required and the cost involved, consideration will be given as to the amount of repairs and renovations that can be authorized.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter No. 107-4-5 of the 8th ultimo, re repairs to Little Red River Indian Day School and Teacher's residence.

I find that it is not necessary to replaster all the walls of the interior of the school, though there is a certain amount of loose plaster should be taken off and repaired. Material for this work had been granted before you received Mr. Munson's report, nothing was allowed for labour and as Mr. Shaw has only one arm it is impossible for him to do the work which will cost approximately $10.00. Material was also granted for interior decorating and Mr. Shaw is paying for the labour personally.

Regarding painting the outside of buildings I admit they are in bad shape as nothing has been done since they were erected. It will take approximately $135.00 to paint the two buildings with two coats of paint, labour will be about $60.00, material $75.00. I may be able to have work done cheaper, but at present it is impossible to have a painter go out and look over the work to be done.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, July 30th, 1937.

Dear Sir,-

I am in receipt of your letter of the 24th instant, with reference to school buildings required in the Carlton Agency, also repairs to a number of the schools.

It was not found possible to provide the funds required for a new teacher's residence at the Montreal Lake School or a new day school on the Big River Reserve. These requests will, however, be again considered when we are preparing our Estimates for the fiscal year 1938-39.

The sum of $150 is all that the Department can spare for repairs and improvements at the day schools in the Carlton Agency this year. You may, therefore, authorize Indian Agent Davis to expend this amount in making the most urgent repairs.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
